newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Volvo Trucks seen making U.S. purchase.
newsitem.headline: Volvo Trucks seen making U.S. purchase.

text.p: Volvo Trucks is seeking to acquire a rival in the North American market in its bid for world leadership in heavy truck production, analysts say.
They said the truckmaker is analysing possible candidates for a takeover -- and most fingers point to Allentown, Pa.-baed Mack Trucks Inc., which is owned by French automaker Renault SA.
"They are most certainly looking to buy something in the North American market," said Hans Westerberg, analyst at Den Danske Bank (DDB).
"Karl-Erling Trogen (chief executive officer of Volvo Trucks) has clearly spelled out that an acquisition is in order to strengthen the company's market position in North America," he added.
Volvo Trucks declined to comment directly.

"There is currently restructuring going on in the truck production industry, and Volvo Trucks is, of course, playing a part in that," spokesman Stefan Lorentzson said in an interview. "Internally, we work with a lot of different scenarios, but, of course, we won't give detailed comment about them."

Volvo Group CEO Leif Johansson has not ruled out the possibility of a North American acquisition, and his stated intention is for Volvo Trucks to become the world's leading heavy truck producer by 2005.

"Johansson has pointed out that an acquisition of some sort is on its way and that it will be significant," said John Lawson at Salomon Brothers in London. "I still think, however, that he will want to wait a couple of quarters after his recent appointment before he is ready to close a big deal."
Analysts say North America is a target for Volvo because its domestic truck industry is not large enough to supply the market on a long-term basis.
A purchase would give Volvo access to a wider sales and distribution network, which would enable it to grow in an important and profitable market.
"In the long run, Volvo Trucks isn't large enough in North America," said Lawson. "The problem is, however, that there are no truck producers to buy."
Although Mack is seen as the most likely candidate, other possible targets include Paccar Inc. of Bellevue, Wash., and Chicago-based Navistar International Corp., analysts said.
"The most probable acquisition is Mack. But it's all down to timing ... whichever board of directors decides to leave the heavy truck market in North America next," DDB's Hans Westerberg said.

"I doubt whether Renault will sell Mack on its own. What might happen is that it looks to find a partnership solution for its European truck operation, and sells Mack in that package," said Philippe Barrier, analyst at Societe Generale in Paris.
